results.notes: This has characteristics of a bolete, but I’ve been unable to find anything matching its description. The pore surface is less than a mm thick and is easily peeled off. It is quite spongy in the cap. It appears to be mycorrhizal always growing at the base of, or very near, the same type of tree (will provide tree ID later). The spore print is white. I have not conducted any chemical tests on it. The aroma and taste are unremarkable. I have only found this in the woods near my home in NE Wisconsin.

results.notes:
Growing on the edge of a pond under planted yellow birch, with a 100 ft scarlet oak nearby. I’ve been finding these at this spot almost every year, but could never get a voucher because they were always moldy, even when very young (seems like H. chrysospermus has never left the area). The two I pick were farther out from the pond and away from their moldy siblings.
Compare this with the other tylops I’ve been finding in a different spot on this property, some 700 ft away as the crow flies (see obs 328145, obs 373449 and obs 426509). After picking the ones in this post, I went to the other spot and found a single purple-capped fruitbody there, which I included in the two photos for comparison.

notes_fields.Macro: This large white gilled fruiting body was found in a grassy lawn (21cm high). Convex cap 10.6cm in diameter. Almost entirely covered in sticky felt-like flakes on top of the cap and most of the stipe (except above the ring). Stipe was bulbous at the ground level (3cm wide) tapering to 1.6cm at top. Stipe hollow except for some of the felt-like material inside (filled about 20%). A few hours after collecting, a clear sticky liquid was exuding from where the stipe connects to the cap. The same liquid was found inside the hollow of the stipe. Gills turned pale yellow as the specimen aged (after collecting) – spore print white.
notes_fields.Micro: At 400x, sphericle spores appeared to be without armor. One spore was measured to be 9.1µm in diameter.

results.notes:
Two groups of three fruitbodies each growing 10 yards apart. The first group was found just a couple of yards away from the mystery Xerocomus sp. of obs 429200.
Each group had two large/mature/post-mature badiomata and one small/immature sporocarp. The fruitbodies are numbered sequentially, starting with the largest one in each group: 1 (l), 2 (m), 3 (s) + 4 (l), 5 (m), 6 (s); see photo captions. All fbs were saved and packed individually.
The colors of the caps in the photos taken in the park are accurate; the stipe colors suffer from a bit of overexposure under natural lighting conditions and no flash.
The dimensions of the two largest basidiomata are recorded below. Thanks to this discovery of this collection, we now know that the species is certainly capable of producing large sporocarps.
Fb #4 (largest): Overall height = 13 cm; cap = planar, 13 cm wide across; cap flesh = 2.2 cm thick above stipe; tubes = 1.4 cm deep max; pores = small at maturity, 2/mm; stipe = curved, 10.5 cm long (measured with a string), of equal 2.5 cm width.
Fb #1: Overall height = at least 12 cm; cap = planar, oval-shaped, 12.2 × 11 cm wide across; cap flesh = 2.2 cm thick above stipe; tubes = 1.1-1.3 cm deep; pores = small at maturity, 2/mm; stipe: curved (measured with a string), ~10 cm long (snapped at base), uniformly 2.3 cm wide.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 27-Feb-23):
This collection was sampled for ITS by Dr. Kudzma. The targeted amplicon was ITS1F ==> LR22, meaning that a full-length ITS and the first 300+ bps of LSU should have been procured as a contiguous sequence under ideal conditions, with at least some overlap between the reads. However, due to unknown technical issues affecting a good number of samples processed late last year, many generated reads came out short/truncated.
In this case, the forward read delivered the first 443 bps of ITS (full-length ITS1 & 5.8S subloci and partial ITS2 sublocus) before the peaks disappeared into the noisy baseline, and the reverse read barely crossed into the 3’ end of ITS2 before the same thing happened. Thus the two reads don’t overlap and cannot be connected. The two sequence fragments are posted to this obsie.
Still, despite this shortcoming, the short reads are long enough for publication in GenBank. The ITS sequence from the forward read matches GenBank accessions of this taxon published by me in the past. The LSU fragment is 100% identical to GB accessions of both P. sclerotiorum and P. pseudoscleroriorum. It’s been noted before, when longer LSU sequences were derived from these collections, that LSU cannot effectively resolve these sister taxa (essentially no barcoding gap), as the pairwise similarity between them is >99%.

results.notes: Found by Dana Hood and Kevin Little in a forested area of a park consisting of mostly oak, hickory, and elm trees and dense underbrush. Growing from a dying oak tree in advanced stages of decay. Several fruiting bodies that are fleshy, bendable, and somewhat kidney shaped with an earthy button mushroom-like smell. Cap coloration ranges from creamy orange/yellow to dark orange/red and some areas of brown/red. Pore surface bright orange and bruises a dark red/brown. Pores angular. Taste is bitter with mild woody and earthy undertones. No reaction to KOH, which contradicts the usual dark purple reaction seen from this species. One specimen collected and vouchered. ITS sequence obtained.

notes_fields.Macro: Specimens were collected from a group of Agaricus emerging near a small vineyard in Bee Co., Texas. No woody vegetation was nearby. A cluster of dark brown free-gilled mushrooms was growing in turf over high pH soil (7.8) influenced by subsoil of caliche. Caps were gray and more of less smooth. Cap margins were smooth. One example cap measured 7.9cm in diameter with a stipe length of 8.0cm (stipe diameter at base 0.9cm, in middle 1.1cm, and at top 0.9cm. Stipes tan, bruising to yellow and were stuffed. Rapid color change to yellow with the application of KOH. Spore print chocolate brown.

results.notes:
Two large, yet still immature (the pores were still covered by the white layer of cheilocystidia), fruitbodies growing in the space between the two clusters of Pulchroboletus of obs 429232. The mixed woods here are dominated by beech, with a few oaks and maples nearby. A few days later I made a collection of two similar boletes growing in a different spot (0.1 mi away), closer to the area where obs 244398 – and other posts mentioned therein – had been observed. MO244398 was found to be a member of the ‘Aereus Clade’ of porcini s.s. by DNA, and it remains to be seen if the 2020 collections are conspecific with it.
The larger basidiocarp had a cap footprint of 12 cm; the cap flesh was 2.2 cm thick above the stipe; the tube were 7-10 mm deep; the curved stipe was 13 cm long (measured with a string) and 2.5 cm wide at apex and below, but widening to 3 cm in the base.

results.notes: Mixed woods (nearest to oak) and sand soil. Scent was indistinct and I did not give it a taste. There were a couple of scattered clumps of 3-4 mushrooms. The smaller/younger caps have dark hairs toward the margin of the cap. The younger specimen’s gills had a greyish purple tint to them while the older was more tan. I don’t believe these to be Russula but the larger one certainly exploded like one when tossed into a tree. The lighting in the pictures really doesn’t show the light purple tones that the caps had.

results.notes: This Amanita is in Section Vaginatea. It looks like Amerifulva with its striate margin and exannulate stem. The deep, white, tubular volva is making me question this. It was growing with pitch pine in sandy soil. This solitary specimen measured 15.5 cm tall with a cap diameter of 11.5 cm once fully expanded.

notes_fields.Macro:
A large number of these were scattered under live oaks next to a golf course. Two mature specimens were collected. The smooth caps were a pale red-orange, and the undersides of the caps were yellow. One cap was 11.5cm x 10.0cm and the other cap was 8.0cm x 7.4cm. The Stipe length for both was 8.0cm. The solid stipes were widened at the base. Both specimens were purple at their bases. The patterning on the stipe had the appearance of tree bark. There was a strong mushroom-like odor.
Bruising anywhere on a specimen caused a rapid (within 30s) color change to deep blue (almost black).
notes_fields.Micro: Ten spores were measured with an average length of 13.4µm and an average width of 6.2µm.

results.notes:
Hortiboletus or Xerocomellus? Two fruitbodies growing between paving stones near mature oaks. The larger fb had a cap footprint of 5 cm. The tubes and pores blued upon injury. The flesh blued erratically above the tubes and the stipe-cap juncture, but not in the stipe itself.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 21-Aug-22; revised 22-Aug-22):
This collection was sampled for ITS by Dr. Kudzma upon my request. The ITS sequence is a full-length consensus derived from two mostly overlapping reads devoid of any heterogeneity or ambiguous positions. The common overlap is 654 bps long, while the spacer itself is 696 bps long.
Based on a visual analysis of BLASTn similarity profiles of North American accessions that are 97.9~99.7% similar to the present sequence, as well as a distance-based tree built in GenBank from these and more genetically distant Hortiboletus accessions, we are possibly looking at a single species with the intraspecific variability of up to 2%. However, this hypothesis needs further support from a ML-based model (both trees to be posted later).
This collection is conspecific by ITS with the following MO posts: obs 299731, obs 327820, obs 373444, obs 418487 and, possibly, obs 326548. Additional collections sequnced by S.D. Russell are posted in iNat. This species appears to be the most common and widespread Hortiboletus in eastern North America. The 2020 Western Xerocomellus/Hortiboletus paper by Frank et al. calls this species H. campestris. The true identity is yet to be determined.

notes_fields.Macro: As I drove to town the other day, I notice this odd-shaped white puffball in the grass beside the road. It looked like a tiny snowman waiting to be decorated. It had one bulge sitting at ground level and a slightly larger bulge on top of that. The fruiting body was 10.8cm tall, the top bulge was 7.5cm in diameter, and the bottom bulge was 7.1cm in diameter. I collected it but did not process it for a couple of days. During that time, the entire outer skin turned chocolate-brown and became very sticky to the touch. I mounted a couple of tissue samples on slides but was not able to find spores.

results.notes:
Found several of these growing gregariously in leaf litter on deadwood chips near a colony of Cantharellus cinnabarinus. Rocky/Sandy soil in a mostly hardwood but mixed forest just above the resevoir. There was also a few clusters of Laetiporus growing nearby.
I have seen these before in the county elsewhere also growing in a similar environment with Cantharellus and above a large water source. If found again, will submit.
